pros:
Workplace and city are low pressure, compared to larger cities.
Cost of living is low.
Work colleagues are excellent to work with, if a bit distant.
Participation in common activities is optional and limited.
Remote working is possible, depending on management.
cons:
While my manager is excellent to work with, there are a lot of procedures, paperwork and upper management issues.
Upper management poor decision-making has led to negative economic outlook across the university, as well as historical difficulties within my own department.

pros: Worked with some nice staff,  took on staff development opportunities and gained a good promotion.
cons: Often it’s if your face fits, too many new staff at management  level restructure teams, make people redundant then bring in people they know to redundant jobs with new titles, thus getting away with it, bad recruitment ie must have certain qualification but successful applicant doesn’t have it, weak management, major restructure resulting in a lot of long term staff being made redundant, new staff are clueless

pros:
They have students and their unique experiences at the heart of all they do and have invested immense amounts of resources in developing this. 

Investment in the campus has matched the increasing demands that have emerged as the city has grown in popularity so they are responsive. 

Very flexible workplace; they treat their staff as professional adults who know the work has to be achieved and it has to be done well but how you do it, do some extent can fit in with lifestyle. They supported me taking a part time role after 36 years of working full time and helped me with this major redevelopment in my life fully appreciating I still wanted to be a significant contributor.

They are a massive part of the community; the University is involved in community projects across the board in ways many would not be aware of and have made a significant difference to many areas of life.

They have a very healthy and responsive attitude towards research; ranging from encouraging those new to the area to take part and 'whet their appetite' to supporting international projects whenever opportunities arise.
cons:
Change is occurring very rapidly to some of the strategic elements of the University and at times it feels as if it is change for change's sake; undoubtedly it won't have been but there is often no immediate evidence supporting a need to change.

The room booking system in the University is unbelievably complicated and inefficient and has been in spite of it being the centre of much apparent change and development. This sadly impacts on the students' learning experience and causes teaching staff much unnecessary stress.

Car parking can be very challenging at busy times; quite why a part time worker cannot purchase a priority car parking permit is difficult to comprehend.

pros: Local countryside is pretty as is the coastline.
cons: Very badly managed, with turnover of almost all senior management (e.g. Vice Chancellor, Pro Vice Chancellors, Deans), sometimes twice per role, over the recent period.  Strategy seems to be one of lowering standards over academic appointments (judged by publications and experience). Student entry requirements must be weak, or the qualifications are diluted, going by the students I taught (nice people, but seemed to find the idea of reading anything to be a bit odd).  Management seemed keen on early retirement or shipped out to very weak universities.

pros:

cons: Its a case of first come first serve so if you want to work on a particular event you need to get in there fast

pros: Great campus, pay and pension. Nice working environment.

job_title: Lecturer in Kingston upon Hull, East Riding of Yorkshire, Yorkshire and the Humber, England
pros: Senior staff at departmental level good at assessing developmental need and helping find resources (internal and external) to access
cons: Bureaucratic legacy can be frustrating! But that seems to be changing now a little. Human Resources are quite sticky, so if you're in an admin post, you may find that frustrating.

job_title: Senior Administrative Role in Hull, England
pros: Easy to access, plenty of places for a coffee and to eat at reasonable prices. Good salary and pension plan.
cons:
If you are new and coming from a different sector, region don't expect to be welcomed with open arms.  If you're lucky you'll be introduced to a number of people when you arrive but once you are ready to start working and start asking questions it will all go quiet and the answer will be to go and ask someone else and be sent in circles.

This is a very endogamic institution both academically and in professional services.  Many couples both working there or family members.  This is the norm, it's accepted and it's run like a club. There are non-written lines of communication different groups and decision making  processes that don't correspond to the published structure, you only know them if you're part of the club.

There is a plan to make the university smaller in number of academic units and number of students. Also to focus on certain academic areas in science and health. 

The income is too reliant on home undergraduate students and as number of these lowers funding becomes a problem. There's a push to attract foreign students with high fees but as the institution's workforce is 90%  local (in academic and admin services) the environment is not the right one. The lack of transparency doesn't help.

The institution has had 3 major re-estructures in the last 5 years so systems can't cope with changes and databases become obsolete very quickly, same with any processes. People know that and keep their own data but as a newcomer you'll be asked to populate data or set up processes for which the people that have been there before already have a non-written process and a full set of data built over the years. 

It's impossible to find who is who and who does what as there is no information in the external pages or the intranet, you only get to know by staying there for 20 years. When you raise a question or a problem you are automatically shut down or sent on an endless conquest for information.

Recently the institution announced that it needed to cut £20million from July 2019 to July 2020 (all over the papers) and would open a Voluntary Exit Scheme, this was suppose to be monitored carefully so the institution won't loose any business critical staff. In reality all applications must have been accepted because some units went over the target they had. In addition at the same time we're letting people go to reduce costs we're also asking part-time staff to increase their working hours, does that make sense? 

People go without Annual Appraisals for years. This is not monitored by senior staff in your unit. I've seen a number of people recruited to a certain job description to then be asked to help on something else that then becomes the job. 

There's very strong culture of communication by e-mail so you can cover your back. I've known of people who have even set up an automatic forward to sent and receive e-mails so they have a back up.
